--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Mattias Fagerlund" <mattias@c...> wrote:
> Hi!
> 
> I've been hacking away at a simple OCR demo using DelphiNEAT. I let
NEAT 
> see a picture (7 x 14 pixels) of a letter and let it choose which
letter 
> it thinks it is (out of 26 letters). Thus, I have 7*14=98 inputs +
1 
> bias. And I have 26 outputs. Creating a connection from every input
to 
> every output leads to 99*26 = 2574 connections per network. 
> 
> Now, I've tried a method where I add X random connections instead of
the 
> full 2574 connections, but so far, the results are depressing.
> 
> Does anyone have an idea for a better method?
> 


While I agree that modular or developmental systems will help tackle
high-dimensional problems like this, I also think that roving eyes
like Darren's shape-recognizer are the right way to go with visual
types of systems.  Humans don't process images all at once, they scan
images with their eyes, and the size of our eyes doesn't change to fit
the problem.  Rather, we use our memory as we process large input
spaces.  A recurrent neural network can be evolved to do the same
thing.

ken
